Submonoid
Let $G$ be a monoid. A subset $H \subset G$ is called a submonoid if $H$ satisfies the following conditions: (i) $e \in H$, (ii) $a, b \in H \Longrightarrow a b \in H$.
Right Coset
Let $G$ be a group and $H$ a subgroup of $G$. A right coset of $H$ in $G$ is a subset of $G$ of the form $Ha = \{ha; h \in H\}$, where $a \in G$.
Subring

A subset S of a ring R is called a subring if S is a subgroup with respect to the addition on R and a submonoid with respect to the multiplication on R. S inherits the laws of composition from R and is itself a ring.
System of Generators of an Ideal

Let $\mathfrak{a}$ be an ideal of a ring $R$. A family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ of elements in $\mathfrak{a}$ is called a system of generators of $\mathfrak{a}$ if $\mathfrak{a}=\sum_{i \in I} R a_{i}$, i.e., if $\mathfrak{a}$ coincides with the ideal generated by the family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$.
Euclidean function
The map $\delta$ in a Euclidean domain $R$ that facilitates the Euclidean division process.
Prime Element

An element $p$ in a unique factorization domain $R$ is called a prime element if it generates a prime ideal, i.e., the ideal $(p)$ is such that if $p$ divides a product of elements in $R$, then $p$ divides at least one of those elements.
Characteristic of a field

Let $K$ be a field (or, more generally, an integral domain) and let $\varphi: \mathbb{Z} \longrightarrow K$ be the canonical ring homomorphism. Furthermore, let $p \in \mathbb{N}$ be a generating element of the principal ideal $\operatorname{ker} \varphi$. Then $p$ is called the characteristic of $K$, and we write $p=\operatorname{char} K$.
Simple Field Extension
A field extension $K \subset L$ is called simple if there exists an element $\alpha \in L$ such that $L=K(\alpha)$. The degree $[K(\alpha): K]$ is referred to as the degree of $\alpha$ over $K$.
Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension

The Galois group, or automorphism group, $\\[\operatorname{Aut}_{\mathbb{F}_q}(\mathbb{F}_{q'})\]$ of a finite field extension $\\[\mathbb{F}_{q'} / \mathbb{F}_q\]$ is the group of field automorphisms of $\\[\mathbb{F}_{q'}\]$ that fix $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$. It is cyclic of order $n$, where $n$ is the degree of the extension.
Solvable group

A group $G$ is called solvable if there exists a chain of subgroups $G_{0} \\supsetneq G_{1} \\supsetneq \\ldots \\supsetneq G_{r}=\\{1\\}$ such that each $G_{i+1}$ is a normal subgroup of $G_{i}$ and the residue class group $G_{i} / G_{i+1}$ is abelian.
Alternating Group

The alternating group on $\{1, \ldots, n\}$, denoted as $\mathfrak{A}_{n}$, is the set of all even permutations in $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$, i.e., those permutations for which $\operatorname{sgn} \pi = 1$. It forms a normal subgroup of index 2 in $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$.
Subset
A subset is a set where all of its elements are also contained within another set.
Definition_Association_Analysis

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: A submonoid is defined within the context of a monoid, implying that the concept of a monoid must be defined first.
A right coset is defined using a group and a subgroup, which implies that the concepts of group and subgroup must be defined first.
A subring is defined as a subset that is both a subgroup and a submonoid of a ring, implying that the concepts of ring, subgroup, and submonoid must be defined first.
The system of generators of an ideal is defined within the context of an ideal in a ring, implying that the concepts of ring and ideal must be defined first.
A Euclidean function is defined within the context of a Euclidean domain, implying that the concept of a Euclidean domain must be defined first.
A prime element is defined within the context of a unique factorization domain, implying that the concept of a unique factorization domain must be defined first.
The characteristic of a field is defined using a field or an integral domain, implying that the concept of a field or integral domain must be defined first.
A simple field extension is defined using the concept of a field extension, implying that the concept of a field extension must be defined first.
The Galois group of a finite field extension is defined using the concept of a finite field extension, implying that the concept of a finite field extension must be defined first.
A solvable group is defined using the concept of a group and subgroups, implying that the concepts of group and subgroup must be defined first.
The alternating group is defined using the concept of permutations and the symmetric group, implying that the concepts of permutations and the symmetric group must be defined first.
